field_reports.summary: GEO: Fire - 02-2025 - Explosion in the Residential House
field_reports.description: As a result of the explosion that occurred on January 14, 2025, 77 families (212 People) were affected and are currently being moved to various hotels. Among them, 58 families are internally displaced persons. The psychosocial support team visited the families displaced to temporary housing areas and studied their situation and needs. As part of the visit, they were left with booklets on overcoming psychological trauma and the Red Cross hotline number, where they can contact in case of need

field_reports.summary: GEO: Other - 03-2025 - Snow Storm in Georgia
field_reports.description:
Since February 21, 2025, western Georgia has been struggling with a severe winter storm, causing widespread damage and humanitarian challenges. The most critical impact was recorded on March 1, but as of today, March 7, the disaster is still ongoing, with heavy snow and extreme weather conditions continuing to affect Guria, Adjara, Imereti, and Mtskheta-Mtianeti. Many villages remain isolated, thousands of people are still without electricity, and emergency responders are facing serious challenges in reaching those in need.

In Guria, snowdrifts continue to block roads, leaving villages like Chokhatauri, Gogole District, and Ozurgeti cut off from essential supplies. Residents of Buknari, Kvenobani, and Basileti remain stranded, while people in Jumati, Konchati, and Kokati face food shortages and worsening conditions. With ongoing snowfall, there is still no clear timeframe for when access to these areas will be restored.

In Imereti, around 30,000 people are still without electricity, and 149 villages remain inaccessible. Schools remain closed, and relief efforts are slowed down by the extreme weather. In Adjara, conditions have not improved, as Batumi continues to face power outages and mobility restrictions due to icy roads. In Khulo, Shuakhevi, and Keda, nearly 20 villages remain surrounded by snow, and some homes are still buried. Reports indicate a serious lack of food, medical supplies, and heating, while avalanche risks remain high.

The death toll stands at three, with recent reports confirming that people have died from collapsed roofs and exposure to freezing temperatures. Emergency responders and military personnel are still working to clear roads and evacuate people from the hardest-hit areas, but the ongoing snowfall makes their work extremely difficult.

The Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) has been active on the ground, providing food, hygiene supplies, and psychological support. However, as the disaster enters its third week, humanitarian needs are growing, and additional aid is urgently required. If conditions do not improve soon, the crisis could escalate further, leaving thousands in life-threatening situations. The priority remains ensuring food, heating, and medical assistance reach the most vulnerable before the situation deteriorates further.

field_reports.summary: GEO: Other - 02-2025 - Impact Report: Heavy Snow in Georgia
field_reports.description:
Since February 20, a rapid deterioration of the weather in West Georgia provoked the humanitarian crisis. Today, February 25, there are critical consequences of the bad weather. To this time and date, three people already lost their lives due to heavy snowfall.

Heavy snowfall affected the Western part of Georgia, especially the Guria region. Many villages are cut off from the outside world, there is no electricity, water, and food supplies are running low. Locals can no longer to walk or move because the roads are covered with snow.

In Chokhatauri municipality, in the villages of Buknari, Kvenobani, and Basileti, about 200 families are left without access to medicines and food, and they do not have the necessary equipment to clear snowy roads and get out of their houses. Snow cover in Nabeghlavi, Tavpanta, Kvabgha, and Chkhakoura reaches 3 meters.  In the Gogole district, also in Khevi, Bzholieti, and Bukhieti, there are around 150 families including persons with disabilities, elderly who are alone, and socially vulnerable populations, also there are families with minor children who need food, hygiene, and medicines assistance. In all the 11 villages there is a delay in the supply of electricity and gas. The roof of one of the houses collapsed, which required the involvement of relevant agencies. The power supply is cut off, there is no way to communicate. 

 

There is a humanitarian crisis in 28 villages in Ozurgeti municipality. There is no electricity, water, food, and the roads are uncleaned. Day care centers are shut down, leaving beneficiaries without food. In the villages of Jumati, Konchati, Baileti, Zomleti and Kokati, the population cannot contact their relatives, and food supplies are running out. In several villages, the roofs of houses collapsed, leaving residents without housing. In the village of Silauri, young children and families need first aid medicines and food. Due to the snow cover, the ambulance cannot reach the population.

 

Due to intense snowfall in Imereti, the educational process in schools and kindergartens is suspended in most of the municipalities. 42 rural roads are closed. Electricity is not supplied to 28,870 electricity users, special teams are working in this direction to restore the supply in a timely manner.

 

Local authorities asked the Georgia Red Cross to help them with food, medicines, human resources, special equipment such as generators, heaters, gas burners and etc. Despite the fact, that the weather in West Georgia got worse since February 20, today, February 25, there are critical consequences of the bad weather. Thus, today, the Georgia Red Cross has been receiving the calls on hotline since early morning, and people ask for food, medicines, and evacuation. Due to the lack of electricity, maybe we won’t receive information soon, as people can’t charge their phones. Also, due to the lack of electricity, Georgia Red Cross can’t reach out to families. 

 

The main needs are food, medicines, candles (which are in short supply in the region), heavy equipment for cleaning the roads, fuel, heaters, alternative energy sources (generators and powerbanks for mobile phones), hygiene products, gas burners, clothes and first aid kits. The number of people evacuated is increasing.

National Environmental Agency (NEA) is announcing that more snowfall and worse weather conditions are expected in the coming days.

The most critical impact was recorded on March 1, but as of today, March 7, the disaster is still ongoing, with heavy snow and extreme weather conditions continuing to affect Guria, Adjara, Imereti, and Mtskheta-Mtianeti. field_reports.summary: GEO: Flood - 05-2024 - Heavy Rains and Floods in Georgia
field_reports.description:
Mtsketa-Mtianeti

On May 26, severe weather caused widespread devastation floods across several regions in Georgia. Huge amount of rainfall during short time, led to significant problems throughout the Mtskheta-Mtianeti region. The devastating floods severely impacted the Tserovani settlement where IDPs are living, the administrative units of Tianeti and Dusheti municipalities, and various villages within the Mtskheta municipality. The flooding caused extensive damage in the villages of Tskhvarichamia, Lisi, Dzegvi, Nichbisi, Zalisi, Tserovani, and the Navdaraantkari administrative units. After several days of heavy rains, residential houses and internal district roads were flooded, bridges and power lines were damaged, and farm plots and agricultural fields were completely destroyed. The electricity supply was cut off to several villages, exacerbating the difficulties faced by the residents.

In Tianeti, the continuous rainfall created severe issues in the administrative units of Artni, Akhalsofeli, Jeboti, Tianeti township, Sion township, Ghulelebi, Nakalakari, and Simoniantkhevi. The road infrastructure and electric transmission lines were significantly damaged, leaving about 100 families cut off from the outside world. Up to 50 families saw their homes and agricultural plots flooded. The population is unable to leave their homes to buy necessary supplies and they are not being provided with drinking water. The villages of Sakhevi, Chiaura, parts of Chabano, and the "building district" in Nakalakari are isolated, compounding the residents distress.

Kvemo Kartli

The Kvemo Kartli region experienced severe flooding on May 26 due to the overflow of the Algeti River, affecting Sadakhlo, Algeti, Kirachmuganlo, Lezhbadini, the town of Marneuli, and an IDP settlement. The flood impacted local citizens, including ethnic minorities and internally displaced persons. The central market area of Marneuli was also damaged. Flood waters destroyed bridges and affected 400 families. Several families needed helicopter evacuations to ensure their safety.

field_reports.summary: Avalanches, Landslides, Floods in Western Georgia
field_reports.description:
As for the Rapid Assessment information, on February 6-7, 2024, Georgia was struck by a series of catastrophic natural disasters, significantly impacting several municipalities. According to the preliminary information, the number of affected families are 550 and this number is increasing. In the regions of Khulo and Keda, heavy snowfall triggered avalanches and landslides, resulting in tragic fatalities and extensive property damage. Particularly poignant was the incident in Zemo Tkhilvana village, where an avalanche buried a house, claiming the life of a 63-year-old woman, and landslides causing widespread destruction in the surrounding areas. Concurrently, the mountainous region of Svaneti, including the Mele village, was severely affected by heavy snowfall and avalanches, leading to infrastructure collapse, blocked roads, and prolonged power outages. In the Lentekhi area, a house was completely destroyed by fire, exacerbated by the inaccessibility for emergency services due to the blocked roads. The Adjara region faced a landslide in the Keda-Tsaniaris area, tragically resulting in the death of a policeman, with the landslide's devastation extending to 10 neighbouring communities, severing crucial connections and isolating villages. This was further complicated by catastrophic floods in Shuakhevi-Kokotauri, leaving Buturauli village in ruins. Similarly, in Samegrelo, 340 families were affected by floods and strong winds that damaged houses and infrastructure, with particular mention of Anaklia, where 16 families suffered extensive flooding and property loss. In Martvili, strong winds caused significant structural damage. The village of Khidikuri in the Shida Kartli region's Khashuri Municipality witnessed overwhelming floods from the Tiliana river, leading to submerged electric substations and extensive damage to residential areas and agricultural fields. Imereti region, specifically the village of Nergeeti in Baghdati, suffered a landslide late at night, causing loss of life and large-scale destruction, burying four houses and leaving several people, including a family of four, missing. This series of disasters across Georgia created a complex emergency scenario, with varying degrees of destruction and humanitarian needs in each affected region.

The affected municipalities by regions:

1. Adjara - Keda, Khulo, Shuakhevi

2. Svaneti - Mele, Lentekhi

3. Samegrelo - Martvili, Tsalenjikha, Anaklia, Chkhorotksu

4. Imereti - Bagdadi, Terjola, Chiatura

field_reports.summary: GEO: Landslide - 2023-09 - Flood and landslide in Guria
field_reports.description:
A devastating landslide and flooding have struck the Guria and Adjara regions in Georgia's western part. According to the Georgian Internal Affairs Ministry's report on Friday, three individuals, including two minors, are currently missing in the aftermath of this disaster.

 

The Public Safety Command Centre has received over 100 notifications from the affected zone. The landslide has resulted in the flooding of residential houses, uprooted trees, and extensive damage to critical infrastructure. Additionally, heavy rainfall and subsequent landslides have cut off several villages in the Guria region, exacerbating the crisis.

 

Search and rescue operations are underway. The Ministry of Internal Affaris reported the discovery of the body of one minor during rescue operations in the village of Jumati. The search for the remaining two missing individuals is ongoing.

 

This natural disaster has caused significant damage to the region's infrastructure, including houses, bridges, and roads connecting villages. Various departments of the Ministry of Interior are actively present on the ground, with mobilized equipment and an active response mode.

 

The Ministry of Internal Affaris urgently advises residents in the affected area not to relocate and to strictly adhere to the instructions provided by its representatives on-site.

 

According to Aleksandre Sarishvili, the mayor of Lanchkhuti, landslides have impacted several villages in the Chochkhati community, resulting in the destruction of at least 10 houses.

 

The Emergency Management Service (112) of Guria and Adjara regions has received more than 100 reports, indicating the widespread impact and urgent need for assistance.

field_reports.summary: GEO: Landslide - 2023-08 - Landslide and Mudslide In Shovi Resort, Georgia #3 (2023-08-04)
field_reports.description:
7 People are declared dead and 36 missing as a consequence of sudden massive landslide and mudslide in the mountainous resort area in Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti as of August 4, 12:00 AM.  

On August 3, Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti Region, a sudden landslide and mudflow occurred in the popular Shovi resort in Racha-Lechkhumi and Kvemo Svaneti administrative Region. he landslide destroyed the roads surrounding to the resorts, demolished bridges and summerhouses. The area is now completely isolated from the rest of the territories and is accessible only by the helicopter. 

The landslide has left a massive trail of destruction, with the key infrastructure severely affected. The central road and bridge leading to the Shovi resort were entirely swept away by the landslide, causing complete disruption to transportation and access to the disaster area. The extent of damage on the roads has hampered the rescue and relief efforts, making the situation challenging for responders. 

Search and rescue operations have been ongoing since the incident occurred. The Ministry of Interior's Emergency Service deployed two helicopters and 400 firefighters and rescuers for the rescue and search operation. The emergency management service, in close collaboration with the relevant Governmental strictures and the Georgia Red Cross, has been working continually to locate and assist those affected by the disaster. Teams are actively conducting search operations throughout the night to find the individuals who are still reported missing. The rescue personnel are demonstrating unwavering determination to locate any survivors and provide immediate assistance to those in need. 210 people, including minors, are evacuated to safety by the time of the report submission. 

The Georgia Red Cross has played a crucial role in supporting the emergency response efforts. Staff and volunteers from the Oni and Ambrolauri branches have been mobilized and are actively contributing their expertise in disaster management, restoring family links, psychosocial support, and first aid. The Red Cross teams are on standby, ready to provide vital assistance to the affected population as soon as they are needed. 

From the beginning of the tragedy, the Red Cross volunteers, alongside other relevant structures, have been actively collecting data on the missing and injured individuals. This critical information is essential for coordinating search operations effectively and ensuring that timely assistance reaches those in distress. Amidst the ongoing rescue efforts, a rescue plane was successfully able to evacuate 210 individuals from the disaster zone. This evacuation has ensured their safety and transportation to a secure location, providing much-needed relief to the affected individuals. 

As the situation continues to evolve, the authorities are closely monitoring the developments and coordinating their response efforts to address the immediate needs of the affected population. The priority remains on saving lives, providing necessary aid, and supporting the impacted communities during this difficult time.

Media Footage

  • Drone footage of the Mudflow/ landslide: https://www.facebook.com/watch?

  • Six people are declared dead https://1tv.ge/news/shovshi-stiqiis-zonashi-mashvelebma-kidev-otkhi-ckhedari-ipoves/

  • Rescue Services are not able to access the demolished summerhouses: https://www.radiotavisupleba.ge/a/32533804.html?fbclid=IwAR1tx8F_jgo18_r3sJCkIZl-MPSl5mPkFhole2zPTj7HbAoeyt4i69U2JgA

  • Emergency Service has resumed the rescue operation: https://1tv.ge/news/shovshi-stiqiis-zonidan-moqalaqeebis-vertmfrenebit-gamoyvana-ganakhlda-foto-video/

contacts.name: Ivar Schram
contacts.title: Programme Coordinator for South Caucasus CCD

field_reports.summary: GEO: Flood - 2023-07 - Heavy Rains in Western Georgia #2 (2023-07-13)
field_reports.description: Through 10-11th of July, Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Imereti, Guria regions and Adjara Autonomous Republic in Georgia experienced a significant disaster caused by heavy rainfall, flooding, and hailstorms. The disaster impacted various areas within Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti and Adjara, affecting both urban and rural settlements. The disaster had a huge impact on the agricultural sector, with flooding damaging agricultural lands, fruit trees and destroying crops in the affected regions. Cattle and poultry were killed. This has significant implications for the livelihoods of the affected population, as agriculture serves as a crucial source of income for many households in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti and Adjara. The heavy flooding profoundly impacted the affected households, causing significant damage to the roofs and ground/first floors of residential houses where families typically store home electronics and stocks of food and hygiene items for long-term use.

contacts.name: Kakha Mamuladze
contacts.title: Deputy Secretary General/Head of Disaster Management Department

contacts.name: Ivar Schram
contacts.title: Programme Coordinator for South Caucasus CCD

field_reports.summary: GEO: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 2023-06 - Flash Floods in Eastern Georgia, Heavy Rainfall in Western Georgia
field_reports.description:
In 15th of June, Gurjaani, a municipality in Georgia, experienced a significant disaster resulting from heavy rainfall, flooding, and hailstorms. The disaster impacted various areas within Gurjaani, affecting both urban and rural settlements. As a consequence of the heavy rainfall, the central streets of Gurjaani municipality and surrounding areas were flooded, causing severe difficulties in transportation and mobility. In addition, the sudden mudflows and landslides resulted in the destruction of roads, blockages caused by fallen trees, and damage to vital infrastructure such as bridges and power transmission towers. Gurjaani, Chumlaki, Tchandari, Vejini, Dzirkoki, Kolagi, Bakurtsikhe, Kodalo villages were flooded, and other state infrastructure such as bridges and inland roads, and power transmission towers were damaged. The disaster also had a detrimental impact on the agricultural sector, with flooding damaging agricultural lands and destroying crops. This has significant implications for the livelihoods of the affected population, as agriculture serves as a crucial source of income for many households in Gurjaani. During the Gurjaani disaster, the heavy flooding had a profound impact on the affected households. As families typically stored basic household items and food on the first floor, the floodwaters resulted in significant damage to essential supplies, appliances, furniture, and various household items. This loss added to the already challenging situation faced by the affected population

Through 10-11th of July, Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti, Imereti, Guria regions and Adjara Autonomous Republic in Georgia experienced a significant disaster caused by heavy rainfall, flooding, and hailstorms. The disaster impacted various areas within Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti and Adjara, affecting both urban and rural settlements. The disaster had a huge impact on the agricultural sector, with flooding damaging agricultural lands, fruit trees and destroying crops in the affected regions. Cattle and poultry were killed. This has significant implications for the livelihoods of the affected population, as agriculture serves as a crucial source of income for many households in Samegrelo-Zemo Svaneti and Adjara. The heavy flooding profoundly impacted the affected households, causing significant damage to the roofs and ground/first floors of residential houses where families typically store home electronics and stocks of food and hygiene items for long-term use.

field_reports.summary: GEO: Flood - 2022-06 - heavy rains and strong wind
field_reports.description:
Through June 21-26, 2022, heavy rains and strong wind seriously affected five municipalities (Tianeti, Dusheti, Tkibuli, Ambrolauri, Senaki and Zugdidi) in eastern Georgia. Central and adjacent streets were flooded, roads were blocked by massive trees, most villages were flooded, as well as bridges and inland roads, houses, road infrastructure, perennials and power transmission towers were damaged. It became necessary to evacuate and move several families to a safe place. In addition, strong winds blew the roof off several houses in Ambrolauri Municipality. people were heavily affected by the emergency. Through June 22-23, local authorities of the affected municipalities officially approached the Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) with the kind request to support the affected population. Based on the information received from the GRCS branches and volunteers involved in the response activities, as well as from the local authorities of the affected municipalities, the heavy rain and the wind caused severe damages of roofs, ground/first floors (where people generally stock food and hygiene items for long-term use) and entrances. Agricultural lands and fruit trees are also destroyed. Agriculture is a primary source of income of the households in affected municipalities of Georgia. The damage caused by the disaster is foreseen to bring a heavy impact on the livelihood of the people affected. Special commission established by the Government of Georgia is calculating the damage caused by the heavy rain in the municipalities of Georgia. 
Georgia Red Cross has mobilized in total 20 volunteers in the affected five branches in affected regions for assessing the situation on the ground. Rapid assessment conducted by the GRCS volunteers also revealed that the main immediate need of the affected population is food and non-food items. The Emergency Management Service (EMS) under the Ministry of Interior in Georgia is actively involved in the liquidation works of the flooding and the landslide in the affected municipalities. Liquidation works include cleaning and restoring the essential parts of the damaged areas, properties, and infrastructures in the immediate aftermath of the emergency.

results.name: GEO: Flood - 2022-06 - heavy rains and strong wind

contacts.name: Olga Dzhumaeva
contacts.title: Head of Delegation for South Caucasus

field_reports.summary: Georgia - Heavy Rains, Floods and Landslides
field_reports.description: Through September 22-24, 2021, heavy rain seriously affected four municipalities in western part of Autonomies Republic of Adjara and Guria Region. 880 people were heavily affected by the emergency. Through September 22-24, local authorities of the affected municipalities officially approached the Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) with the kind request to support the affected population, in total 1780 people/445 families with the basic food and non-food items. Based on the information received from the GRCS branches and volunteers involved in the response activities, as well as from the local authorities of the affected municipalities, the heavy rain caused severe damages of roofs, ground/first floors (where people generally stock food and hygiene items for long-term use) and entrances. The heavy rain also caused the landslide in some parts of the affected municipalities. The houses of 20 households in Adjara and 12 household in Guria region have been totally destroyed. The Government allocated safe space/shelter for them immediately. One woman in Adjara, whose house was destroyed by the landslide, received an injury. She was hospitalized and the doctors already operated her. Agricultural lands and fruit trees are also destroyed. Agriculture is a primary source of income of the households in Adjara and Guria Regions in Georgia. The damage caused by the disaster is foreseen to bring a heavy impact on the livelihood of the people affected. Special commission established by the Government of Georgia is calculating the damage caused by the heavy rain in the municipalities of Georgia. One injury of the woman was recorded. Georgia Red Cross has mobilized in total 38 volunteers in both branches in affected regions for assessing the situation on the ground. Rapid assessment conducted by the GRCS volunteers also revealed that the main immediate need of the affected population is food and non-food items. No other NGO or private sector entity is providing support to the affected population due to limited funding available and absence of disaster management projects. The Emergency Management Service (EMS) under the Ministry of Interior in Georgia is actively involved in the liquidation works of the flooding and the landslide in the affected municipalities. Liquidation works include cleaning and restoring the essential parts of the damaged areas, properties, and infrastructures in the immediate aftermath of the emergency. Based on the information received from the Georgia Red Cross local branch staff and volunteers in a coordination with the local government, a total of 445 households (1780 people) are affected by the emergency in the following municipalities:

results.summary: Through September 22-24, 2021, heavy rain seriously affected four municipalities in western part of Autonomies Republic of Adjara and Guria Region. 880 people were heavily affected by the emergency. Through September 22-24, local authorities of the affected municipalities officially approached the Georgia Red Cross Society (GRCS) with the kind request to support the affected population, in total 1780 people/445 families with the basic food and non-food items. Based on the information received from the GRCS branches and volunteers involved in the response activities, as well as from the local authorities of the affected municipalities, the heavy rain caused severe damages of roofs, ground/first floors (where people generally stock food and hygiene items for long-term use) and entrances. The heavy rain also caused the landslide in some parts of the affected municipalities. The houses of 20 households in Adjara and 12 household in Guria region have been totally destroyed. The Government allocated safe space/shelter for them immediately. One woman in Adjara, whose house was destroyed by the landslide, received an injury. She was hospitalized and the doctors already operated her. Agricultural lands and fruit trees are also destroyed. Agriculture is a primary source of income of the households in Adjara and Guria Regions in Georgia. The damage caused by the disaster is foreseen to bring a heavy impact on the livelihood of the people affected. Special commission established by the Government of Georgia is calculating the damage caused by the heavy rain in the municipalities of Georgia. One injury of the woman was recorded. Georgia Red Cross has mobilized in total 38 volunteers in both branches in affected regions for assessing the situation on the ground. Rapid assessment conducted by the GRCS volunteers also revealed that the main immediate need of the affected population is food and non-food items. No other NGO or private sector entity is providing support to the affected population due to limited funding available and absence of disaster management projects. The Emergency Management Service (EMS) under the Ministry of Interior in Georgia is actively involved in the liquidation works of the flooding and the landslide in the affected municipalities. Liquidation works include cleaning and restoring the essential parts of the damaged areas, properties, and infrastructures in the immediate aftermath of the emergency. Based on the information received from the Georgia Red Cross local branch staff and volunteers in a coordination with the local government, a total of 445 households (1780 people) are affected by the emergency in the following municipalities:

field_reports.description: on the 8th of October, 2021, residential building collapsed in Batumi, Georgia, leaving 8 people dead and several still missing. Batumi Branch volunteers have been mobilized immediately and  were deployed to support effected population. Around 50 Batumi Branch volunteers were supported population with PSS activities, distributing water, distribution facemasks and antiseptic liquids. Red Cross volunteers are organizing distribution of the food for the local population, rescuers and police. All activities on the ground are coordinated with GRCS HQ office.

contacts.name: Olga Dzhumaeva
contacts.title: Head of Delegation for South Caucasus

field_reports.description:
On 29 April 2021, heavy rain, hail, and wind-affected Kakheti Region of Georgia.
As a result of the hail and heavy rain agricultural lands and fruit trees have been destroyed. The rain (approx. 120-125mm) suddenly started which caused serious damages in the Municipalities. 
Through May 1-3, the Local Authorities of the affected Municipalities officially approached the Georgia Red Cross Society with the kind request to support the affected population with the basic food and Hygiene kits. 
Besides the damages mentioned above, yards, entrances, basements, and first floors of many houses and buildings have been flooded in affected Municipalities. Roofs are destroyed.
The Emergency Management Service and all relevant ministries are involved in the liquidation works of the flooding in the affected Municipalities.
Based on the information received from the Georgia Red Cross local branch volunteer groups and the local Government In total, 1300 households (3900 people) are affected by the disaster in Lagodekhi, Gurjaani, and Sagarejo  municipalities:

results.name: Strong hail and heavy rain in Kakheti Region, Georgia

contacts.name: Olga Dzhumaeva
contacts.title: Head of country cluster for South Caucasus

field_reports.summary: Heavy Rains and Floods in Georgia
field_reports.description: On October 1st, 2020, heavy rain affected 140 households in different districts of Batumi. (The exact number of the households affected will be shared with the Georgia Red Cross Society later).   1st floors and the basements of the houses are flooded. Home appliances and furniture of the families are totally damaged. Food supplies are spoiled. After the rapid assessment, there are the needs for the first need items for the affected population.
